info.text: The default category for questions shared in context 'gsele'.

questiontext.text: When I cut my thumb it [bled] so I put a bandage on it.
In the high wind the old tree was [blown] down.
My parents were young when they [bought] their house
How many people [came] to the concert?
Yesterday I used scissors to [cut] the photo out of the magazine
Last summer we sat on the beach and [drank] orange juice.
We searched until we [found] the missing photo.
It happened so long ago I have [forgotten] the details.
It was so cold that the water had [frozen]
The students [have] a new subject to study.
I [have] a blue on and my brother [has] a red one.
When he shouted your name he [meant] no harm.
Until last year my father [taught] French.
I [was] waiting for the kettle to boil
I played tennis with Paul last week and I [beat] him.
After going to the gym for three months I [became] stronger.
When I was at school I did not [know] how to play guitar.
Last Saturday I [drank] four cups of coffee
I saw John on Saturday and I [gave] him the keys.
When my mother walked to the car I [held] her hand.
When I was at the hotel I [kept] my in my suitcase.
Last Saturday I [left] the party at midnight
Last year I [ran] in the London marathon.
When his new book came out I [read] it as soon as I could.
I borrowed half the money from the bank and by summer I had [repaid] it all.
Last summer I [rode] my bicycle across northern England.
I [saw] and interesting TV program about London.
When we were at the zoo [saw] an elephant.
When I was on holiday I [slept] until 10 O'clock every day.
Last year I [took] my mother on holiday.
I could not sleep because the air conditioning was [making] a noise.
I could not sleep because the air conditioning was [making] a noise.

Type the end letter to form the Simple Past/Past Participle of the verb i

e.g. I shout, yesterday I shouted.

I bend, yesterday I [bent]

I spend, yesterday I [spent]

I walk, yesterday I [walked]

I lend, yesterday I [lent]
By the time I arrived the game had already [begun].

incorrectfeedback.text: It would be more common to say "the game had already started", but begun is also correct.

questiontext.text: The house [shook] every time a plane landed.
It was so cold that the water had [frozen].
The got a good price when they [sold] their house.
The machine was very loud and I could not hear what he [said].
On my birthday we were [driven] in a taxi to the restaurant.
We [were] waiting for the kettle to boil.
I remember the day when we first [met].
When you went to the shop, [did] you buy [some] milk.
When we get there [what] do you want to do for lunch?
I cannot find the drill, [where] did you put it?
You should have been here an hour ago, [why] are you so late?
A new born dog is called a [puppy]

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and red is a color.

is incorrect.

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case brown is a color so comes before leather which is a material (what the shoes are made of)

partiallycorrectfeedback.text:

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case beautiful is an opinion, old is an age, and blue is a color and Chinese is the origin

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case large is size, old is age and  wooden is material

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case large is size, old is age and  wooden is material

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case incredibly is an opinion and fast is a (sort of) size.

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case lovely is an opinion and so comes before big

There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case brown is a lovely is an opinion and so becomes before old.

questiontext.text:
Put the descriptive words in the correct order. 

She wore a  [beautiful] [long] [red] dress

generalfeedback.text:
The rule in English is that the order of adjectives (describing words) should be

  • Quantity or number
  • Quality or opinion
  • Size
  • Age
  • Shape
  • Color
  • Proper adjective (often nationality, other place of origin, or material)
  • Purpose or qualifier

incorrectfeedback.text:
According to this article in Wikipedia (retrieved 25/10/2016)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjective#Adjective_order

In general, the adjective order in English is:

  1. Determiners — articles, adverbs, and other limiters.
  2. Observation — postdeterminers and limiter adjectives (e.g., a real hero, a perfect idiot) and adjectives subject to subjective measure (e.g., beautiful, interesting), or objects with a value (e.g., best, cheapest, costly)
  3. Size and shape — adjectives subject to objective measure (e.g., wealthy, large, round), and physical properties such as speed.
  4. Age — adjectives denoting age (e.g., young, old, new, ancient, six-year-old).
  5. Color — adjectives denoting color (e.g., red, black, pale).
  6. Origin — denominal adjectives denoting source of noun (e.g., French, American, Canadian).
  7. Material — denominal adjectives denoting what something is made of (e.g., woolen, metallic, wooden).
  8. Qualifier — final limiter, often regarded as part of the noun (e.g., rocking chair, hunting cabin, passenger car, book cover).

questiontext.text: Last night we watched a [wonderful old] movie.

incorrectfeedback.text:
There is a general rule that adjectives should go in the the following order

Opinion,Size,Age,Shape,Colour,Material,Origin,Purpose

So in this case wonderful is an opinion  so comes before old (age)

questiontext.text: That video was not [as] good [as] the last one.
Is the ice cream [better] than the pie?
Taking the train is faster [than] going by bus.
This quiz is harder [than] the last one.
This test is [more difficult than] the last one.
My new flat is bigger [than] the old one.
My new phone is similar [to] my old phone
